tr.td: For preventing Charge and Expence in Elections of Members to serve in Parliament.
Persons elected to serve in Parliament not to give Money, &c. to Elector.See 49 G.III. c.118.
Offenders disahled from serving upon such Election in Parliament.
To prevent false and double Returns of Members to serve in Parliament.
Returns contrary to the last Determination of the Commons, adjudged false.
Party aggrieved to recover Double Damages and full Costs.
Clerk of the Crown to enter Single and Double Returns of Members, and Alterations made therein, in a Book.
All Persons may have free Access thereto.
Book, or true Copy thereof, Evidence.
Clerk of the Crown not making Entry, or altering or unduly giving Certificate or neglecting Duty —Penalty £500, and Loss of Office, and Incapacity.

Continuance of Act.
This Act made perpetual, 12 Ann. stat.I.c.15.
For the continuing, meeting, and sitting of a Parliament, in case of the Death or Demise of His Majesty, His Heirs, and Successors.
Parliament not dissolved by the Demise. of His Majesty or his Successors, but may sit Six Months after, unless sooner prorogued or dissolved—as by Stat. 1 W. & M. Sess. 2. c. 2.
If no Parliament sitting at the King's Demise, then last preceding Parliament to sit.
Proviso for Power of the King to prorogue or dissolve Parliament, and also for Stat.6 & 7 W.& M. c. 2.
For the further regulating Elections of Members to serve in Parliament, and for preventing the irregular Proceedings of Sheriffs and other Officers in the electing and returning such Members.
Forty Days to be between the Teste and Return of Writ of Summons.

Writs to be issued with Expedition, and to be delivered within Three Days (a) to the proper Officer, who is to indorse the Receipt, and deliver Precept to the proper Officer, give public Notice of Election (b), and otherwise to proceed as herein mentioned.
(a) Six Days to Officers of the Cinque Ports, 10 W.III. c.7.§2.
(b) As to the Hours when Notice to be given, see 33 G.III. c.64.
Sheriff, &c. not to take Fee for making out, delivering, &c. of Writ or Precept.

On Election of Knights of Shires, Sheriff to hold County Court, and proceed to Election.
No County Court in England to be adjourned to a Monday, Friday, or Saturday, 6 G. II. c. 23. § 1.;but that Section repealed, 10 G.II. c. 18.§ 14. As to Yorkshire, see §8. post.See 18 G.II. c.18.§10.
Sheriff to appoint Poll Clerks, who are to be sworu.
Sheriff or Deputy to administer the Oath, and to appoint Inspector of Poll Clerks.
Freeholder, before polling, to take Oath.

Form of Oath.
This Oath repealed, 10 Ann. c. 23. § 3. and another Oath thereby appointed, which is repealed,18 G.II. c.18.§ 1., and another Oath thereby appointed.
Such Freeholder, &c. committing Perjury Penalty of Stat. 5 Eliz.c. 9.
Sheriff or Deputy to proceed to polling.
No unnecessary Adjournment to take Place.
Sheriff to deliver Copy of the Poll for a reasonable Charge.
Proviso as to Trustees, Mortgagees, &c. voting.

Conveyances to multiply Votes, &c. void.
See further, 10 Ann. c. 23. § 1.; and as to Devises by Will, see 53 G. III.c.49
Infants not to vote, or be elected—Penalty.

Times of holding County Court in Yorkshire.
See Note to § 3.ante.
Poll for Knights of Shire for County of Southampton adjourned from Winchester to Newport.

For continuing several Acts of Parliament.
Stat. 19 & 20 Car.II.c.10. continued for Seven Years, § 1. 16.and17 Car.II.c.2 made perpetual,§ 2.—4 W..& M. c.20.made perpetual, § 3.— Stat. 4. W.& M. c. 22.made perpetual,§ 4.; but Section 2. of this Act repealed, 47. G.III.Sess 2.c. lxviii. § 2.
For preventing irregular Proceedings of Sheriffs and other Officers in making the Returns of Members chosen to serve in Parliament.
Returning Officer to make Return of Election within 14 Days to Clerk of the Crown.
Fees to be paid by such returning Officer.
Such Fees to be charged to the Crown.
Officer of the Cinque Ports allowed Six Days, for Delivery of Precept.
For preventing any Inconveniences that may happen by Privilege of Parliament.
Actions may be brought against Peers and Members of Parliament, and Judgment given therein, during the Intervals of Parliament as herein mentioned.
Proviso against arrest of Members during Time of Privilege; but Process may be had against Peers as herein mentioned.
Proviso for Proceedings against Members of the House of Commons during the Intervals of Parliament.
And for Proceedings against Peers and Members in Courts of Equity and Duchy Court.
Members not to be arrested during Time of Privilege.
Proviso in respect of Bar by Statute of Limitations, where Plaintiff stayed by Privilege of Parliament.
Proceedings at Law or in Equity against Debtors to the King, not stayed by Privilege of Parliament.

No further Jurisdiction given to Courts than before this Act.
This Act amended and Privilege restrained, 11 G.II. c.24;extended to Scotland,10 G. III. c.50. § 6.
Stat. 7 & 8 W. III. c. 7. § 7. continued for 11 Years.
For the easier obtaining Partitions of Lands in Coparceny, Joint Tenancy, and Tenancy in Common.

After Process of Pone, or Attachment returned on Writ of Partition, if the Tennant do not enter an Appearance within 15 Days, Court may proceed to examine the Demandant's Title, give Judgment by Default, and award a Writ of Partion, which on Proceedings as herein mentioned, shall conclude all Persons.
If Tenant or other Person shall in One Year after Judgment entered, or after determination of Inability thew good Matter in bar of Partition, &c. the Court may suspend or set aside such Judgment.
In what Case Appellant to pay Costs.
Where High Sheriff cannot be present at the Execution of a Judgment in Partition, Under Sheriff in Presence of Two Justices may proceed thereupon.
Tenants before Division to be Tenants of Part, divided under the same Conditions, &c.
Landlords to make good to Tenants their said Parts, as before Partition made.
Sheriffs, Under Sheriffs, &c. to give due Attendance for executing Writs of Partition—Penalty.
Demandant not paying Sheriffs, &c. his Fees, Court to award the same.

Continuance of Act.
This Act made perpetual, 3 & 4 Ann. c. 18. § 2.

For completing the Building and adorning the Cathedral Church of St. Paul, London, and for repairing the Collegiate Church of St. Peter, Westminster.
See1 Ann. Stat.2. c. 12. § 6.
This Act altered by 9 Ann. c. 22. § 9.
Anglesea, James Earl of, and Katherine Countess of, his Wife.
Auverquerke, Henry de Nassau, Seignor de.
Arran, Charles Lord Weston Earl of.
Bagneol, Peter, Senault Daniel, and others.
Baker, Sydenham, Gent. —John, Gent.—Henry, an Infant.
Barrington, Sir Charles, Bart. and his Children.
Barry Richard, Esq., Sorocold, George, Gent., and Soame, Richard.
Barkham, Sir William, Bart., deceased, and, his Children.
Boscowen, Hugh, Esq. and Charlotte his Wife.
Bulkley, The Right Honorable Elizabeth Viscountess.
Byde, Thomas, Esq., an Infant.— Barbara.
Carcassonet, John Francis de, and others.
Cary, Susanna, Widow.— Nicholas, Esq. deceased, and others.
Chamberlain, Sir James, Bart., an Infant
Child, Sir Josiah, Bart. deceased, and Cooke, Sir Thomas, Knight.
Cordoso, Gasper, and Wedd, Herman Vant, and others.
Cowslade, Thomas, an Infant, and others.
Dalby, Thomas, Esq. and Dorothy his Wife.
Dawson, Joseph, Esq. and his Daughters.
Delagard, Isaac, and Batero, John, and others.
Dillon, Sir John, and — Boyle, Mary.
Gainesborough, Wriothesly, Baptist, late Earl of, deceased.
Gardiner, Joseph, and Sarah his Wife, and Ridges, William, Esq. deceased.
Guybon, Sir Francis, and —Dame, Isabella, his Wife.
Higgons, John, Gent., and Alice his Wife, and others, their Children.
Hopwood, Thomas, Gent., and Elizabeth his Wife.
Hore, Charles, Esq., and Elizabeth and Mary his Daughter and Wife.
Howland, Jeffery and Samuel, and Tavistock, Lord Marquess of, and his Lady.
James, William, Gent., and Wife and Children.
Janson, Bryan, Esq., deceased, and his Wife and Children.
Jones, Richard, Esq[uire]., Minor, and Gufford Mary, Spinster, Minor.
Kilmorey, Robert Lord Viscount, an Infant.
Knott, William, Gent., and his Wife.
Leigh, Edward, Esq[uier] and Jane his Wife.
Lisburne, John Lord Viscount, and Lady Viscountess, his Wife.
Macclesfeild, Charles Earl of, and Ann his Wife.
Marsham, Sir Robert, Knight and Bart.

Merefield, John.
— Robert, and his Widow and Children.
Montargiere, John de Philiponeau Sieur de.
Nodes, Richard, and his Wife and Children.
Norfolk, Duke of, and Mordant, Lady Mary.
Panton, Thomas, Esq[uier] and Mary, his Wife.
Pitt, George, Esq[uire] and others —John, Gent.
Price, Edward, Esq[uire] and his Children.
Robinson, Sir Thomas, Baronet, and Ann, his Sister.
Rochford, Earl of, and Children of.
Sands, Mary.—William, Esq[uire] and their Children.
Stockley, Jeoffery, deceased, and his Daughter.
Stoner, Thomas, Esq[uire]— John, Esq[uire] deceased.
Stoughton, Sir Nicholas, Bart.—Sir Lawrence, Bart., deceased.
Trevisa, Peter, Esq[uire] deceased, and his Widow and Children.
Vandertyd, Francis, Vandersnersch, Agneta, Lowman, Henry, and Tresor, James Gabriel le.
Vyner, Sir Robert, Knight and Baronet, deceased.
Walrond, Humphrey, Gent., and his Son and Daughter.
Walter, Sir William, Baronet, deceased.—Lady Mary, his Wife.
Weslyd, Cyriac, Esq[uire] and his Wife and Children.
Wessell, Leonard, Esq[uire] and Sarah his Wife.
Wyndham, Sir Edward, Bart.—Hopton, Esq[uire]—Sir William, Bart.

For repairing the Collegiate Church of Saint Peter Westminster.
Altered by 9 Ann. c. 22. § 9.
Piracies, &c. may be enquired of at Sea or upon Islands, and by Commission under the Great Seal or Admiralty Seal.

Court to consist of Seven at least.
See further, 46 G. III. c. 54.
Three may call together a Court of Seven.
What Persons may sit and vote in such Court.
Court may issue Warrants for Persons accused, and Attendance of Witnesses, and examine upon Oath, and give Sentence of Death.
Oath of President, who is to administer the same to every Person sitting and voting upon the Trial.
Register to read the Articles against the Prisoner.
Proceedings, where Prisoner pleads not guilty.
Prisoner may bring Witnesses for his Defence, and may be heard.
President to collect the Votes of the Court.
Judgment to be given in Presence of the Prisoner.
Natural born Subjects committing Acts as herein mentioned, deemed and upon Conviction, to suffer according to Stat.28 Hen. VIII. c. 15.
Commanders of Ships, &c. turning Pirates, &c. or attempting to corrupt other Commanders, &c. to suffer as Pirates.
Persons aiding Pirates, &c. who shall there upon act, adjudged Accessaries.
Persons concealing Pirates, &c. or Vessels, &c. taken by such, adjudged Accessaries.
Accessaries tried, and to suffer as Principals, under Stat. 28 Hen. VIII. c. 15.

The said Stat. in force.
Accessaries deemed Principals, and to suffer as such, 8 G. I. c. 24. § 3.

Where Officers and Seamen killed or wounded in defending Ship which shall be brought to Port, Judge of the Admiralty, &c. may levy £2 per Cent. upon the Owners, &c. for Benefit of such Officers and Seamen, or their Widows and Children, as herein mentioned.
Rewards to Officers of Conspiracy, to destroy or run away with Ship.
Jurisdiction of Commissioners for Trial of Pirates, under Stat. 28. Hen. VIII. c. 15. and this Act, in determining Offences and issuing Warrants.
Governors of Plantations, &c. to assist Commissioners and their Officers.
How Commissioners for Trial of Offences within the Cinque Ports to be directed.
And how Trials thereupon to be had.

After 29th Sept. 1700, Masters of Merchants Ships forcing Men on Shore, &c. —Punishment.
This Act continued for 7 Years, &c. 5 & 6 Ann. c. 34. § 3. and during 1 G. I. Stat. 2. c. 25. § 17. which Act is made perpetual, 9 G. I. c. 8. §3. and this Act made perpetual, 6 G. I. c. 19. §3. Offenders against this Act to be tried as directed by 28 H. VIII. c. 15.—4 G. I. c. II. § 7. Persons guilty of High Treason upon the Sea, may be tried as by this Act, 18 G. II. c. 30. § 1. This Act extended to Offences under 37 G. III. c.71. § 4., which however seems to be expired; as to standing mute in Cases of Piracy see 12 G. III. c. 20. This Act recited, 58 G. III. c. 98.
For preventing Frauds and regulating Abuses in the Plantation Trade.
No Plantation Goods to be exported or imported, or carried from one Plantation to another, but in Ships built and owned in England, Ireland, or Plantations, and navigated as herein mentioned.
Proviso for Prize Ships, and for certain Foreign-built Ships, on Forfeiture of Ship and Goods.
Proviso for Exportation and Importation in certain Prize Ships, and for Masts, &c. in certain Foreign-built Ships.
Governors; &c. of Plantations to take Oath. to observe Acts for securing Plantation Trade.
Before whom such Oath to be taken.
Neglecting to take such Oath, or Neglect in their Duty.

Removal and Penalty £1,000.
See further, 8 & 9 W. III. c. 20. §69.—4 G. III. c. 15. § 39.
Officers appointed by Governors to give Security to Commissioners of Customs in England for Performance of Duty.
Governor liable until Security given, and Appointment approved by Commissioners of Customs.
Ships coming into and going out of Plantations, &c. subject to like Regulations as Ships in this Kingdom, under Stat. 14 Car. II. c. II.
Power of Officers of Plantation Trade to visit and search Ships, take Entries, make Seizures, &c. as Powers of Officers of Customs in England, under Stat. 14 Car. II. c. II.

Wharfingers, &c. assisting in the Rescue of Goods, or in resisting Officers—Penalty.
Explained, 7 G. III. c. 46. § 10. and Writ of Assistance granted.
Assistance to be given to Officers.
Officers subject to Penalties as Officers of Customs in England, under Stat. 14 Car. II. c. II.
In Actions against Officers, General Issue may be pleaded.
How Penalties not particularly mentioned, disposed of.
Claimer reputed to be the Owner.
Notwithstanding Payment of the Duties therein mentioned, no Goods to be laden till Security given as required by Stat. 12 Car. II. c. 18. § 19.–22 & 23 Car. II. c. 26. § 6.
Laws, &c. in force in the Plantations repugnant to the aforesaid Laws, or to this Act, or to future Laws, declared void.
Where Governor of Plantation has reasonable Suspicion of false Certificates, &c.
Counterfeiting Certificate, Cocket, &c. or using the same.
The Treasury and Commissioners of Customs may appoint Officers in Ports, &c. of Islands, &c.
In all Actions Juries to be Natives of England or Ireland, or born in the Plantations.

Places of Trust in Courts of Law or Treasury, to be held by Natives of England, Ireland, or Plantations.
As to which see 20 G. III. c. 10. § 3.
Recital of Stat. 22 & 23 Car. II. c. 26. § 6
What Description of Persons only are to be named as Sureties in said Bonds.

Condition of such Bonds.
As to Prosecution on such Bonds, 8 Ann. c. 13. § 23.

Plantation Goods not to be put on Shore in Scotland or Ireland, but on Condition herein mentioned—Penalty.
See 4 G. II. c. 15.
Proviso for Ships driven by Stress of Weather, &c. into Ireland.
Persons claiming Right in American Islands, &c. not to alien, but to natural born Subjects without Licence from the King in Council.
Governors appointed by Proprietors to be approved by the King, and to take the Oaths—Penalty.
No Ship deemed British or Plantation-built, until registered as herein mentioned.

Oath of built of Ship, &c. on registering.
This Oath repealed, 26 G. III. c. 60.§ 9, 10. Qu. if Sections 16, 17, and 18. of this Act be thereby repealed.See further as to Registry, 15 G. II. c. 31. §1.
Oath attested and registered to be deliveredto the Master, and Duplicate of suchRegister transmitted to the Commis-sioners of Customs in London.
Penalty on Ship not having made Proof ofbuilt—Exception.
Proviso for special Registry of Prize Ships.
Exemption of Fishing Boats, &c. fromNecessity of Registry.
On changing the Name of registered Ship,Register de novo.
Sale to be endorsed on Certificate of Registry.

td.emph: This Act enforced by 4 G. III. c. 15.§ 33. 39. As to Foreigner contract-ing for Share without Consent of Owner, 13 G. III. c. 26. the Provisions of this Act extended to Vesselsbuilt in the Isle of Man, 7 G. III.c. 45. § 16. and to Vessels of 15 Tons and upwards, 26 G. III. c. 60.§ 3. and see § 21. and for Tenor ofIndorsement, § 16.—Master detainingCertificate, 28 G. III. c. 34. § 13.—34 G. III. c. 68. § 18–42. G. III. c. 61. § 20, 21.; and as to § 19. ofthis Act, see 34 G. III. c. 68. § 21. His Majesty may by Order in Council,make Regulations respecting Trade toand from Cape of Good Hope, notwith-standing this Act, 46 G. III. c. 30. § 1.

tr.td: For punishing Governors of Plantations inthis Kingdom for Crimes by them com-mitted in the Plantations.

How and where Oppressions by Governors,&c. of Plantations abroad, tried.
See further, 42 G. III. c. 85.
For supplying some Defects in the Lawsfor the Relief of the Poor of this King-dom.

Persons coming to inhabit, and bringingwith them a Certificate under the Churchwardens' Hands, &c. of anyother Parish, &c. of being Inhabitants of such other Parish, &c. and such Cer-tificate being allowed, the said otherParish to provide for them wheneverthey become chargeable.

In what Case removed.
But no Settlement gained by Certificate, unless he rent £10, or executesome Parish annual Office, Stat. 9W. III. c. 11. ; and no Apprenticeor bired Servant of Certificate Manto gain Settlement by Servitude or Ap-prenticeship, 12 Ann. stat. 1. c. 18.§ 2. For Regulations as to Witnessesto Settlement, Certificates, and the Reimbursement of Overseers, 3 G. II.c. 29. § 8 and 9. See also as to Validity of Indentures and Certificates, through Churchwardens, &c. not sworn in, 54 G. III. c. 107. §1.
Persons receiving Alms, their Wives,Children, &c. to wear a Badge on the Shoulder of right Sleeve.
Churchwardens, &c. relieving poor Personsnot wearing such Badge—Penalty 20s.
See 22 G. III. c. 83. § 35. ; but as to re-peal of this Section, see 50 G. III. c. 52.
Justices in Sessions, on Appeal to them concerning the Settlement of any poorPerson, to award Costs.
Persons ordered to pay Costs living out ofJurisdiction, Justice of County, &c.where such Person inhabits may causethe Money to be levied.
If no Distress, Imprisonment in CountyGaol.
Single Persons not deemed to have a goodSettlement under One Year's Service.

Poor Children appointed Apprentices pur-suant to Stat. 43 Eliz. c. 2.: those towhom they are appointed bound to executeIndenture, and to provide for them ac-cording to the Indenture signed by theJustices, &c.—Penalty £10.

Persons to whom poor Children appointed,may appeal.
See 32 G. III c. 57.

Appeal against Order for Removal deter-mined at Sessions.
Costs upon Appeal from Rate to be ordered as by this Act, 17 G. II. c. 38. §4. So as to Costs uponAppeal from Acts by Constable, &c.18 G. III. c. 19. §5.
Proviso for Promise, &c. to take Poor back.

And for Justices of Peace at Saint Alban'shearing Appeals.
By 9 G. I. c. 7. § 7. the like Provisionis made for the Borough of SaintPeter and Hundred of Nassaboroughin Northamptonshire. Removal of the Poor before they become actuallychargeable prevented, 35 G. III.c. 101.; and Justices of Peace may suspend Order of Removal, 49 G. III.c. 124. §1.
For explaining an Act made the last Ses-sion of Parliament, for supplying someDefects in the Laws for the Relief of thePoor of this Kingdom.
No Certificate Person adjudged settled,unless he rent a Tenement of £10 perAnnum, or execute a Parish Office.
For Relief of Poor Prisoners for Debt orDamages
Persons being in Prison for Debt, &c. on25th Dec. 1695, in the Cases herein mentioned released.
Justices of Peace making Order for Discharge, to give Gaolers, &c. an Oath
Sheriff, &c. refusing to appear or takeOaths—Penalty.
Prisoner discharged must take an Oath—Form of Oath.
Taking the Oaths, &c. how performed, andgiving Notice to Creditors.
Act not to extend to certain Persons inExecution.
Debtors to the King, &c. not entitled to Discharge.
Judgment still good against Lands, &c. ofPrisoner—And Creditors may take outnew Execution.
Upon Action of Escape against Justice of the Peace, Sheriff, &c. General Issue may be pleaded—Double Costs.

If Prisoner discharged be again arrested for Debt contracted before Discharge, and upon shewing Duplicate of Discharge, Officer shall refuse to set him at Liberty, he may apply to the Judges or other Persons herein named, and be set at Liberty upon certain Terms.
And such Prisoner may plead the General Issue.
No Man under 40 Years of Age to be discharged during the present War with France, unless he will enlist or procure one to enlist as a Soldier, &c.
Act not to extend to Persons who have committed Felony, &c.
For preventing the Growth of Popery.
After the 25th March 1700, Persons apprehending Popish Bishop, &c. and prosecute to Conviction of saying Mass, &c. Reward of £100, without Fee, on Certificate of Conviction, &c.
In case of Dispute touching Reward, Judge, &c. to apportion same by his Certificate.
In case of Death of Sheriff before Payment of Reward his Successor to pay the same.
Sheriff repaid by Treasury on producing Certificate.
Popish Bishop, &c. saying Mass, &c. or Papist, &c. keeping School—Perpetual Imprisonment within the Kingdom.

After 29th Sept. 1700 any Person educated in the Popish Religion, within Six Months after attaining 18, not taking the Oaths of Allegiance and Supremacy and subscribing Declaration of Stat. 30 Car. II. Stat. 2. c. 1. as herein mentioned, disabled as herein mentioned, and the Protestant next of Kindred to have the Lands of such Person without Account, except in case of wilful Waste.

After 10th April 1700 Papists disabled to purchase Lands as herein mentioned.
Astorepeal of Sections 1–4. see 18 G. III. c. 60. § 1. and see 43 G. III. c. 30.
Proviso for saying Mass, &c. in the Houses of Foreign Minister, if the Priest be not a Subject of His Majesty.
Reward of £100 in Stat. 3 Jac. I. c. 5. to be to the Sole Use of the Informer.
After the 25th March 1700 Popish Parents compelling Protestant Children to change their Religion as herein mentioned, Lord Chancellor may make Order herein.
For enabling Posthumous Children to take Estates as if born in their Fathers Life-time.
Proviso respecting Estates already come into Possession, &c.

entry.head: Prisoners and Prisons See Creditors. Poor Prisoners.
Privately Stealing in Dwelling house See Felons.
Prizage Wines See Cunnage and Poundage.

tr.td: For the taking, examining, and stating the Public Accounts.
Stat. 2 W. & M. Sess. 2. c. 11.–4 W. &M.c.11.–5 & 6 W. & M. c. 23.–6 & 7 W. & M. c. 9. revived and continued.
Treasury empowered to issue and pay Allowances to Clerks, &c. as by Stat. 2. W.& M. Sess. 2. c. 11.
Commssioners empowered to take Account of Monies granted as herein mentioned.
Two of the first named Commissioners to be sworn—Oath.

The other Commissioners to take the same Oath before the said Two.
This Act continued, 13 & 14 W. III. c. 1. but now expired.
For appointing Commissioners to take, examine, and determine the Debts due to the Army, Navy, and for Transport Service, and also an Account of the Prizes taken during the late War.
